workflow.name: Auto create & publish X-threads (Twitter) with GPT via Telegram & approval loop
workflow.description:
# AI X (twitter) Threads Bot with Approval Loop

This n8n workflow transforms your Telegram messenger into a personal assistant for creating and publishing X-Threads. You can simply send an idea as a text or voice message, collaboratively edit the AI‚Äôs suggestion in a chat, and then publish the finished thread directly to X just by saying ‚ÄúOkay.‚Äù

## What You‚Äôll Need to Get Started
Before you can use this workflow, you‚Äôll need a few prerequisites set up. This workflow connects three different services, so you will need API credentials for each:

***Telegram Bot API Key***: You can get this by talking to the  [‚ÄúBotFather‚Äù ](https://telegram.me/BotFathers)on Telegram. It will guide you through creating your new bot and provide you with the API token.
New Chat with Telegram BotFather

***OpenAI API Key***: This is required for the ‚ÄúSpeech to Text‚Äù and ‚ÄúAI Agent‚Äù nodes. You‚Äôll need an account with OpenAI to generate this key.
OpenAI API Platform

***Blotato API Key***: This service is used to publish the final post to X. You‚Äôll need a Blotato account and to connect your X profile there to get the key.
Blotato platform for social media publishing


Once you have these keys, you can add them to the corresponding credentials in your n8n instance.

## How the Workflow Operates, Step-by-Step
Here is a detailed breakdown of how the workflow processes your request and handles the publishing.

### 1. Input & Initial Processing
This phase captures your idea and converts it into usable text.

Node Name	Role in Workflow
Start: Telegram Message	This Telegram Trigger node initiates the entire process upon receiving any message from you in the bot.
Prepare Input	Consolidates the message content, ensuring the AI receives only one clean text input.
Check: ist it a Voice?	Checks the incoming message for text. If text is empty, it proceeds to voice handling.
Get Voice File	If a voice note is detected, this node downloads the raw audio file from Telegram.
Speech to Text	This node uses the OpenAI Whisper API to convert the downloaded audio file into a text string.
### 2. AI Core & Iteration Loop
This is the central dialogue system where the AI drafts the content and engages in the feedback loop.


AI: Draft & Revise Post	The main logic agent. It analyzes your request, applies the ‚ÄúSystem Prompt‚Äù rules, drafts the post, and handles revisions based on your feedback.
OpenAI Chat Model	Defines the large language model (LLM) used for generating and revising the post.
Window Buffer Memory	A memory buffer that stores the last turns of the conversation, allowing the AI to maintain context when you request changes (e.g., ‚ÄúMake it shorter‚Äù).
Check if Approved	This crucial node detects the specific JSON structure the AI outputs only when you provide an approval keyword (like ‚Äúok‚Äù or ‚Äúapproved‚Äù).
Post Suggestion Or Ask For Approval	Sends the AI‚Äôs post draft back to your Telegram chat for review and feedback.
AI Agent System Prompt (Internal Instructions - English)
The agent operates under a strict prompt that dictates its behavior and formatting (found within the AI: Draft & Revise Post node.



### 3. Publishing & Status Check
Once approved, the workflow handles the publication and monitors the post‚Äôs status in real-time.

Node Name	Role in Workflow
Approval: Extract Final Thread Posts	Parses the incoming JSON, extracting only the clean text ready for publishing.
Create post with Blotato	Uses the Blotato API to upload the finalized content to your connected X account.
Give Blotat 5s :)	A brief pause to allow the publishing service to start processing the request.
Check post status	Checks back with Blotato to determine if the post is published, in progress, or failed.
Published?	Checks if the status is ‚Äúpublished‚Äù to send the success message.
In Progress?	Checks if the post is still being processed. If so, it loops back to the next wait period.
Give Blotat other 5s :)	Pauses the workflow before re-checking the post status, preventing unnecessary API calls.
4. Final Notification
Node Name	Role in Workflow
Send a confirmation message	Sends a confirmation message and the direct link to the published X post.
Send an error message	Sends a notification if the post failed to upload or encountered an error during processing.
## üõ†Ô∏è Personalizing Your Content Bot
The true power of this n8n workflow lies in its flexibility. You can easily modify key components to match your unique brand voice and technical preferences.

### 1. Tweak the Content Creator Prompt
The personality, tone, and formatting rules for your X content are all defined in the System Prompt.

Where to find it: Inside the AI: Draft & Revise Post node, under the System Message setting.
What to personalize: Adjust the tone, change the formatting rules (e.g., number of hashtags, required emojis), or insert specific details about your industry or target audience.
### 2. Switch the AI Model or Provider
You can easily swap the language model used for generation.

Where to find it: The OpenAI Chat Model node.
What to personalize:
Model: Swap out the default model for a more powerful or faster alternative (e.g., gpt-4 family, or models from other providers if you change the node).
Provider: You can replace the entire Langchain block (including the AI Model and Window Buffer Memory nodes) with an equivalent block using a different provider‚Äôs Chat/LLM node (e.g., Anthropic, Cohere, or Google Gemini), provided you set up the corresponding credentials and context flow.
### 3. Modify Publishing Behavior (Schedule vs. Post)
The final step is currently set to publish immediately, but you might prefer to schedule posts.

Where to find it: The Create post with Blotato node.
What to personalize:
Consult the Blotato documentation for alternative operations. Instead of choosing the ‚ÄúCreate Post‚Äù operation (which often posts immediately), you can typically select a ‚ÄúSchedule Post‚Äù or ‚ÄúAdd to Queue‚Äù operation within the Blotato node.
If scheduling, you will need to add a step (e.g., a Set node or another agent prompt) before publishing to calculate and pass a Scheduled Time parameter to the Blotato node.

workflow.name: Create &Publish X-Threads (Twitter) with GPT-5 via Telegram Bot & Approval Loop

parameters.content:
## AI LinkedIn Content Bot with Approval Loop

Transform your Telegram into a LinkedIn content assistant. Send ideas via text or voice, collaborate with AI to refine posts, and publish directly to X with a simple "ok" or "approved".

### How it works

1. **Send your idea** - Message your Telegram bot with text or voice notes
2. **AI drafts content** - GPT analyzes your input and creates a X-optimized post with hashtags
3. **Iterative refinement** - Request changes (tone, length, style) until satisfied
4. **Approve & publish** - Say "ok" or "approved" to trigger automatic LinkedIn posting via Blotato
5. **Get confirmation** - Receive a direct link once your post is live

### Setup steps

1. **Telegram Bot** - Create a bot via @BotFather and add the API token to credentials
2. **OpenAI API** - Add your OpenAI key for AI generation and voice transcription
3. **Blotato Account** - Connect your LinkedIn profile at [Blotato](https://blotato.com/) and add API credentials & Connect with your X-Account
4. **Customize the AI** - Edit the system prompt in "AI: Draft & Revise Post" to match your brand voice and content style

### Customization tips

- **Adjust tone & style** - Modify the system prompt to change formality, emoji usage, or hashtag count
- **Switch AI models** - Swap GPT-4o-mini for more powerful models in the OpenAI Chat Model node
- **Schedule posts** - Change Blotato operation from "create" to "schedule" for delayed publishing

options.systemMessage:
Keep the confirmation/approval process, but change the output format as follows:

1. Your Core Task
Step 1: First understand and structure the user‚Äôs thoughts


Analyze the user‚Äôs message and explicitly structure it into:


Topic


Goal (e.g., reach, show expertise, recruiting, personal branding, leads)


Target Audience


Tonality (e.g., factual, personal, bold, inspiring)


Key message (one main core idea)


Important examples, stories, data or arguments the user mentions or clearly wants included




If information is missing, unclear, or contradictory:


Ask targeted follow-up questions before you write a thread draft.


Ask at most 3 precise questions per round so you don‚Äôt overwhelm the user.


Phrase questions clearly and in a bullet-like style so they are easy to answer.




If needed, briefly research on the internet to clarify the context:


Do this when the user refers to current events, numbers, trends, studies, people, tools, or products that you are not sure about.


Use this research to:


Use terms correctly


Check the plausibility of numbers or statements


Add short, relevant context where it increases value for the reader




If sources are conflicting or something is uncertain, mention this briefly and neutrally instead of inventing certainty.




Apply scientifically grounded prompting methods:


Decomposition: Break the user‚Äôs request into sub-tasks:


clarify goal


clarify target audience


define the key message


define the structure of the 5 tweets (beginning, middle, end)


define the call-to-action




Step-by-step reasoning (Chain-of-Thought):


First, lock in the goal and target audience.


Then formulate one clear key message.


Split that key message into 5 logical steps (one for each tweet).


From that, derive hook, narrative arc, and closing.




Self-check / reflection before sending a draft:


Does the thread match the defined target audience?


Is the tonality consistent?


Does each tweet add a clear step, value, or perspective?


Are there obvious factual errors, contradictions, or confusing jumps?






Only after this understanding and structuring step is done, you propose a 5-part thread for X.

2. Create a 5-part Thread for X
Create a 5-part thread (5 separate posts/tweets) based on the structured analysis:


Tweet 1 (Hook):


Strong, curiosity-driving hook in the first 1‚Äì2 lines.


Make immediately clear what the thread is about and who it is for.




Tweets 2‚Äì4 (Main body):


Build a clear narrative or logical progression with value, story, examples, or insights.


Each tweet should:


Convey one main point (step in a process, an insight, a lesson, or a concrete example).


Be understandable on its own, but still clearly part of the overall thread.






Tweet 5 (Conclusion & Call-to-Action):


Short conclusion or strongest insight.


Optionally add a call-to-action, e.g.:


Ask a question to spark replies


Invite to share experiences


Suggest following the account, sending a DM, or checking out a resource






Hashtags & format for X:


Use hashtags sparingly and intentionally, primarily in the last tweet (or naturally inside tweets).


Use about 3‚Äì8 relevant hashtags (mix of niche + broader ones).


Ensure good readability:


No emoji spam


Clear sentences, straightforward language


Each tweet should be easy to scan and read on mobile







3. How to Present Your Suggestion to the User
Always present your draft first as a normal text suggestion, not as JSON.
Use a clear structure like:
Proposed X Thread:


Tweet 1: ‚Ä¶


Tweet 2: ‚Ä¶


Tweet 3: ‚Ä¶


Tweet 4: ‚Ä¶


Tweet 5: ‚Ä¶


Optionally add a 1‚Äì2 sentence summary of the overall message of the thread.
Then ask for feedback, for example:

‚ÄúAny changes? (tone, length, more/less personal, more expert content, different hashtags, different structure of the thread?)‚Äù


4. Handling Feedback
If the user requests changes:


Explicitly interpret what should change:


tone (more/less bold, more/less personal)


length (shorter/longer tweets)


content focus (more examples, more data, more emotional story, more actionable tips)


structure (different order of tweets, stronger hook, stronger conclusion)


hashtags


language (e.g. German vs. English, ‚Äúyou‚Äù vs. more formal wording)




Then adjust the thread specifically based on this feedback, without randomly rewriting everything.


Output again only the updated thread suggestion, e.g.:


Updated X Thread Proposal:


Tweet 1: ‚Ä¶


Tweet 2: ‚Ä¶


Tweet 3: ‚Ä¶


Tweet 4: ‚Ä¶


Tweet 5: ‚Ä¶


Then ask again whether further changes are desired.

5. Final Approval & JSON Output
If the user writes ‚Äúapproved‚Äù, ‚Äúok‚Äù, ‚Äúlooks good‚Äù, ‚Äúfine‚Äù, ‚Äúpasst‚Äù, ‚Äúship it‚Äù, ‚Äúfreigeben‚Äù or anything clearly meaning approval:


Return only the following JSON, with no additional text, no Markdown, no explanation:


{
  "thread": [
    "Tweet 1 ‚Äì final text including hashtags if used",
    "Tweet 2 ‚Äì final text",
    "Tweet 3 ‚Äì final text",
    "Tweet 4 ‚Äì final text",
    "Tweet 5 ‚Äì final text"
  ]
}

Important rules:


Never output JSON before explicit approval.


Before approval, always respond with a normal, human-readable suggestion (no JSON).


The final output after approval must consist of only one JSON object with exactly one field:


thread = an array with exactly 5 strings (one for each tweet in the final X thread).

parameters.text: There was an error uploading your post.

nodes.name: Post Suggestion Or Ask For Approval

parameters.content:
## 1. Capture Input

Receives Telegram messages and converts voice notes to text using OpenAI Whisper

## 2. AI Content Creation

Generates LinkedIn posts and handles revision requests through conversational memory

## 3. Approval & Publishing

Detects approval keywords, extracts final content, and posts to X via Blotato

## 4. Status Monitoring

Polls Blotato API to verify publication and sends confirmation with post link to Telegram

main.node: Post Suggestion Or Ask For Approval

data.details:
The IF node can be used to implement binary conditional logic in your workflow. You can set up one-to-many conditions to evaluate each item of data being inputted into the node. That data will either evaluate to TRUE or FALSE and route out of the node accordingly.

This node has multiple types of conditions: Bool, String, Number, and Date & Time.
